content: The "Rural Nursing Promotion Act" establishes a Nurse Distance Education Pilot Program. The Nurse Distance Education Pilot Program aims to increase accessibility to nursing education by providing assistance to individuals in rural areas, promoting nursing study at all levels, creating more slots for nursing students, and establishing new nursing education programs at higher education institutions. To be eligible for a grant under the Pilot Program, an entity must submit an application to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. Increasing the domestic supply of nurses and physical therapists. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, with the Secretary of Education, must submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2008, on the source of newly licensed nurses and physical therapists in each State. The report should include data on teachers at institutions of higher education for each related occupation, regardless of length of service, for the most recent 3-year period available. The report to Congress by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in collaboration with the Secretary of Education, must include data on newly licensed nurses and physical therapists in each State for the most recent 3-year period. It should also address barriers to increasing the supply of nursing faculty and domestically trained nurses, as well as identify individuals receiving their initial nursing license and those licensed by endorsement from another State. Additionally, the report should detail the number of individuals who received their professional education in the United States versus outside the United States. Recommendations of strategies to be utilized by Federal and State governments to remove barriers, including addressing barriers to advancement for other healthcare workers. Recommendations for amendments to Federal laws. Recommendations for amending Federal laws to increase the supply of nursing faculty, domestically trained nurses, and physical therapists, as well as providing incentives for nurse educators and training facilities. It also mentions collaborating with other federal agencies and countries to address health worker shortages caused by emigration. SHORTAGE OCCUPATIONS. During the period from the enactment of the Rural Nursing Promotion Act to September 30, 2017, certain aliens described in section 203(b) can seek admission to the United States for labor in shortage occupations designated by the Secretary of Labor. During the period from the enactment of the Rural Nursing Promotion Act to September 30, 2017, aliens can seek admission for labor in shortage occupations designated by the Secretary of Labor, with exceptions to nondiscrimination requirements under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to provide exceptions for family-sponsored and employment-based immigrants, as well as a process for reviewing petitions for certain aliens within 30 days.
